title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: ---- "But still,  When summer smiled on sweet Bowhill,  And July's eve, with balmy breath,  Waved the blue-bells on Newark heath,  When throstles sung in Hareheadshaw,  And corn was green on Carterhaugh,  And flourished, broad, Blackandro's oak,  The aged harper's soul awoke," etc.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: And so werode by Philiphaugh, Carterhaugh, Bowhill, and Newark, he pouring outall the way his picturesque anecdotes of former times--more especiallyof the fatal field where Montrose was finally overthrown by Leslie.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: And so we rode by Philiphaugh, Carterhaugh, Bowhill, and Newark,  he pouring out all the way his picturesque anecdotes of former times — more especially of the fatal field where Montrose was finally overthrown by Leslie.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: The good Duke of Buccleuch's solitary exemption from these heats of Carterhaugh, might read a significant lesson  to minor politicians of all parties on more important scenes.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: I have no doubt the Sheriff" of the Forest was a prouder man, when he saw his boy ride about Carterhaugh  with the pennon of Bellendon, than when Platoff

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: " On Monday, 4th December, there was played, upon the extensive plain of Carterhaugh, near the junction of the Ettrick and Yarrow, the greatest match at the ball which has taken place for many years.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: The misunderstanding being thus closed, they appear to have counselled and co-operated together in the most cordial fashion, in disciplining their rural allies for the muster of Carterhaugh — the Duke of Buccleuch's brother-in-law, the Earl of Home, having appointed the Shepherd his Lieutenant over the Yarrow Band, while the Sheriff took under his special cognizance  the Sutors, i.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: — Quarrel and Reconciliation with Hogg — Football Match at Carterhaugh — Songs on the Banner of Buo cleuch — Dinner at Bowhill — Design for a piece of Plate to the Sutors of Selkirk — Letters to the Duke of Buccleuch, Joanna Baillie, and Mr. Morritt.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: The author of " the Lay " would rather have seen his heir carry the Banner of Bellenden gallantly at a foot-ball match on Carterhaugh, than he would have heard that the boy had attained the highest honours of the first university in Europe.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: As we looked up to Carterhaugh, hia conversation ran naturally upon Tamlane and Fair Janet, and the ballad recounting their adventures ; then it ran upon the Dii agrestes, ghosts and wizards, Border anecdotes and history, the Bar, his own adventures as advocate and as sheriff; and then returning to ballads, it fell upon the old ditty of Tom o' the Linn, or Thomas O'Linn, which is popular alike, I believe, in Scotland, and in some parts of England, and of which I as well as he had boyish recollections.

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: ^* She prinked hersell and prinned hersell By the ae light of the moon, And she 's awa' to Carterhaugh To speak wi' young Tamlane.'*

title: Spare hours.
author: Brown, John
snippet: " She prinked hersell and prinned hersell By the ae light of the moon, And she 's awa' to Carterhaugh To speak wi' young Tamlane."

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: The placeselected for this spirit-stirring match was the extensive plain of Carterhaugh, near the junction of theEttrick and Yarrow, not far from the scene of thebattle of Philiphaugh.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: One heroine, Mrs Park of Carterhaugh, who hadbeen lately married, and whose husband was at adistant market, might well have hailed the excusefor his non-appearance; but instead she sent hischarger and uniform to meet him on his way home,that he might join his companions-in-arms.
